questions.question_text:
A new program manager joins a multi-year program that has been underway for almost a year. During interviews, several stakeholders state that they do not understand how the program will help the organization.
At the next stakeholder meeting, what should the program manager present to address their concerns?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
"How" is the key word.

Selected Answer: C
Answer should be C. Business case and roadmap.

comments.content:
C also works 
C. Business and program roadmap

The business and program roadmap would be the most appropriate document to present in order to address concerns about how the program will help the organization. This document typically includes a chronological representation of the program’s intended direction, major milestones, decision points, and the linkage between the business strategy and the program work. It provides a high-level overview of how the program aligns with organizational goals and how it is expected to progress over time, which can help stakeholders understand the program’s purpose and expected outcomes.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is the right answer.

choices.C: Earned value management, financial reporting systems, performance measurement techniques, and program management information systems.
choices.B: Interviewing, SWOT analysis, run chart, and matrix-based charts.
choices.D: Delphi technique, scatter diagram, Pareto chart, and organization charts.
choices.A: Program management performance variances, business criteria reweighting, root cause identification, and statistical sampling.

questions.question_text: The program sponsor requests a weekly performance report. The tools and techniques to monitor and control program performance include which of the following?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is the right answer.

Selected Answer: C
Earned Value Management (EVM): This is a widely used project management tool that integrates the project scope, schedule, and cost for performance measurement and analysis. It is crucial for tracking program progress and performance against the plan.

Financial Reporting Systems: These systems provide insights into the financial aspects of the program, including budget, expenditures, and financial forecasts. They are essential for tracking the financial health of the program.

Performance Measurement Techniques: These techniques involve various methods to assess the performance of the program against its objectives, including qualitative and quantitative measures.

Program Management Information Systems (PMIS): PMIS are systems used to plan, schedule, and control program activities. They provide a structured way of managing and reporting on program progress and performance.

Selected Answer: A
A should be the right answer.
C is the right answer since the performance report' must include EV

questions.question_text:
The chief executive officer reminds a program manager that a program must deliver a 30% reduction in customer complaints by the end of the year.
Where is this expectation documented?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
30% reduction is customer complaints is clearly a program benefit and should be part of the benefit management plan.

Selected Answer: C
C. Benefits Management Plan.

The Benefits Management Plan is a document that outlines the expected benefits of a program, how these benefits align with the organizational goals, and how they will be measured and tracked. In this case, the specific target of a 30% reduction in customer complaints is a quantifiable benefit that the program is expected to deliver. This plan would detail not only this benefit but also the methods for measuring the program's success in achieving it, and how this aligns with the broader objectives of the organization.

Selected Answer: C
C is the right answer.

Selected Answer: C
C is appropriate answer for a couple of reasons. Firstly, the strategic plan will provide visibility of the objectives of the program to the new board members. Secondly, the benefit management plan will help the board member understand the relationships/mapping between objectives and benefits. Though the most appropriate answer should be the ToRs of the program board.

Selected Answer: A
A is the right answer

C is the right answer.

questions.question_text:
A two-year program is coming to an end. Many of the initial governance board members have moved from their current posts or left the company. Several new members have joined, but have a short association with the program, which changes the board's expectations and focus. During the final phase gate review, some board members are uncertain of their roles and expectations in the process.
How should the program manager handle this situation?

choices.C: Review the strategic plan and benefits management plan with the board
choices.D: Present the final program status, costs, and schedule reports
choices.B: Prepare a program change request utilizing new board member input
choices.A: Review the final program outcome with the program sponsor

questions.question_text: A program manager is working with the sponsor, stakeholders, and steering committee to formulate a program's benefits sustainment and transition plan. What should the program manager do to create this plan?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
ECO III Task 3
Develop a sustainment plan that identifies the processes, measures,
metrics, and tools necessary for management of benefits beyond the
completion of the program in order to ensure the continued realization
of intended benefits.

choices.C: Interview stakeholders, and revise the benefits management plan to provide new insight into the program's execution and benefits sustainment period.
choices.D: Update the benefits management plan, and provide a copy to the organization responsible for measuring the sustainment period.
choices.B: Assign creation of the benefits sustainment plan to the organization responsible for monitoring and controlling the sustainment period.
choices.A: Identify key measures to compare expected benefits in the benefits management plan with actual performance once benefits sustainment and program transition starts.
